fr:title.text: Regular expression matching

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We have seen the syntax of regular expressions in both concrete and abstract form. What about semantics, i.e. what do regular expressions actually do? The meaning of a given regular expression over an alphabet \Sigma is a matching predicate on strings over \Sigma that says when a given string is matched by the regular expression. In this course, we are particularly interested in the class of formal languages that can be recognised by regular expressions, and later on we will develop tools that allow us to show that some formal languages are too complex to be recognised by regular expressions. In the meanwhile, we will first explain how matching works.

fr:title.text: The matching relation for regular expressions

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The matching relation for regular expressions

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The matching relation u\mathrel {\textsf {matches}}R is given by an inductive definition over \Sigma ^\star \times \mathsf {Regexp}_{\Sigma }.
We will write \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (R\right )\mathclose {}} for the formal language matching or “recognised” by the regular expression R:

We can also obtain a version of the matching relation between strings over \Sigma and concrete regular expressions by relational composition with the (transpose of) the parsing relation. Alternatively, we can simply write the concrete syntax as a mere notation (to be eliminated by the reader immediately) for the abstract syntax. In fact, that is what we will do in the future.

fr:title.text: Examples of regular expression matching

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Consider regular expression matching over the alphabet \Sigma ={\mathopen {}\left \{a,b\right \}\mathclose {}}.

html:ol.html:li: a\vert b is matched by each symbol in \Sigma .
(a\vert b)* is matched every string over \Sigma .
b(a\vert b)* is matched by any string over \Sigma that starts with a b.
((a\vert b)(a\vert b))* is matched by any string of even length over \Sigma .
(\underline {\epsilon }\vert a)(\underline {\epsilon }\vert b)\vert bb is matched just by the strings \epsilon , a, b, ab, and bb.
\varnothing b\vert a is matched only by the symbol a.

fr:title.text: Questions about regular expression matching

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Here are some questions for discussion.

html:ol.html:li: Is there an algorithm which, given a string u and a regular expression r, computes whether or not u matches r?
In formulating the definition of regular expressions, have we missed out on some practically useful notions of pattern?
Is there an algorithm that will compute whether two regular expressions generate the same language?
Is every formal language of generated by a regular expression?

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We will come back to these questions in subsequent lectures. In the meantime, we can say:

html:ol.html:li: Is there an algorithm which, given a string u and a regular expression r, computes whether or not u matches r? Yes. One very simple way is to simply use the rules of Definition as a search algorithm, but this is not very efficient; better ways to decide regular expression matching can be achieved using finite automata, which we will study in the next lecture.

In formulating the definition of regular expressions, have we missed out on some practically useful notions of pattern? Yes! For example, it can be useful to specify a range of symbols (including all symbols!) over an alphabet like most practical regular expression libraries allow. A more sophisticated example is complementation, where a string matches \mathord {\sim }(r) if and only if it does not match r. We will ultimately see that the complement of any regular expression already exists—but it can be useful to include it as a built-in feature.
Is there an algorithm that will compute whether two regular expressions generate the same language? Yes, but we will need the theory of finite automata to see that this is the case.
Is every formal language of generated by a regular expression? No: we will ultimately learn a technique, called the pumping lemma to find counter-examples.

fr:title.text: Closure of injections under identity and composition

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Closure of injections under identity and composition

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The identity function is an injection and the composition of injections yields a injection.
The identity function is clearly injective, as a_0=a_1 implies a_0=a_1.

Let f\colon A\rightarrowtail B and g\colon B\rightarrowtail C be injections. To show that the composite function g\circ f\colon A\to C is injective, we fix a_0,a_1\in A to check that g{\mathopen {}\left (f{\mathopen {}\left (a_0\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}} = g{\mathopen {}\left (f{\mathopen {}\left (a_1\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}} implies a_0=a_1. Because g is injective, we have f{\mathopen {}\left (a_0\right )\mathclose {}}=f{\mathopen {}\left (a_1\right )\mathclose {}}; therefore, because f is injective, we have a_0=a_1 as desired.

fr:title.text: Closure of surjections under identity and composition

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Closure of surjections under identity and composition

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The identity function is a surjection and the composition of surjections yields a surjection.
For the identity function on a set A, we must check that for all a\in A, there exists an element a'\in A such that a'=a. Of course, we choose a' := a.

Let f\colon A\twoheadrightarrow B and g\colon B\twoheadrightarrow C be two surjections. To show that g\circ f\colon A\to C is a surjection, we fix c\in C to exhibit some a\in A such that g{\mathopen {}\left (f{\mathopen {}\left (a\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}} = c. Because g\colon B\twoheadrightarrow C is surjective, there exists b\in B such that g{\mathopen {}\left (b\right )\mathclose {}} = c. Becuase f\colon A\twoheadrightarrow B is surjective, there exists a\in A such that f{\mathopen {}\left (a\right )\mathclose {}} = b. Thus we have g{\mathopen {}\left (f{\mathopen {}\left (a\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}=g{\mathopen {}\left (b\right )\mathclose {}}=c.

fr:title.text: Invariance under isomorphism

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For all sets A,B,X,Y, we have A\cong X \land B\cong Y\implies \mathrm {Rel}{\mathopen {}\left (A,B\right )\mathclose {}}\cong \mathrm {Rel}{\mathopen {}\left (X,Y\right )\mathclose {}}.

Fix bijections f\colon A\to X and g\colon B \to Y. We will define a bijection H\colon \mathrm {Rel}{\mathopen {}\left (A,B\right )\mathclose {}}\to \mathrm {Rel}{\mathopen {}\left (X,Y\right )\mathclose {}}.
Next, we check that H^{-1} is simulatneously a retraction and a section of H.
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \begin {aligned} H^{-1}{\mathopen {}\left (H{\mathopen {}\left (R\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}} &= g^{-1}\circ H{\mathopen {}\left (R\right )\mathclose {}}\circ f\\ &= g^{-1}\circ {\mathopen {}\left (g\circ R\circ f^{-1}\right )\mathclose {}}\circ f\\ &= {\mathopen {}\left (g^{-1}\circ g\right )\mathclose {}}\circ R\circ {\mathopen {}\left (f^{-1}\circ f\right )\mathclose {}}\\ &= \mathsf {id}_{B}\circ R\circ \mathsf {id}_{A}\\ &= R \\ H{\mathopen {}\left (H^{-1}{\mathopen {}\left (S\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}} &= g\circ H^{-1}{\mathopen {}\left (S\right )\mathclose {}}\circ f^{-1}\\ &= g\circ {\mathopen {}\left (g^{-1}\circ S\circ f\right )\mathclose {}}\circ f^{-1}\\ &= {\mathopen {}\left (g\circ g^{-1}\right )\mathclose {}}\circ S\circ {\mathopen {}\left (f\circ f^{-1}\right )\mathclose {}}\\ &= \mathsf {id}_{Y}\circ S\circ \mathsf {id}_{X}\\ &= S \end {aligned}

fr:title.text: Closure of bijections under identity and composition

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Closure of bijections under identity and composition

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The identity function is a bijection, and the composition of bijections yields a bijection.
The inverse to the identity function \mathsf {id}_{A}\colon A\to A is simply itself.

Fix bijections f\colon A\to B and g\colon B\to C, so that we have inverses f^{-1}\colon B\to A and g^{-1}\colon C\to B. The inverse to the composite function g\circ f\colon A \to C is the composite f^{-1}\circ g^{-1}\colon C \to A. The section/retraction conditions follow by those for f and g using the associative and unit laws of composition.

fr:title.text: Closure of functions under identity and composition

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Closure of functions under identity and composition

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Functions are closed under identity and composition.

We have already seen in Theorem that partial functions are closed under identity and composition. Therefore, it suffices to argue that the identity partial function is total, and that the composition of two total partial functions is total.

html:ol.html:li: We must show that for all a\in A, there exists a' \in A such that a\mathrel {\mathsf {id}_{A}} a'; unfolding the definition of the identity relation we may choose a' = a.

Given f\colon A\to B and g\colon A \to C, we must check that for all a\in A, there exists some c\in C such that a\mathrel {{\mathopen {}\left (g\circ f\right )\mathclose {}}}c. By the definition of relational composition, we must show that there exists b\in B and c\in C and such that a\mathrel {f}b and b\mathrel {c}. We choose b = f{\mathopen {}\left (a\right )\mathclose {}} and c = g{\mathopen {}\left (b\right )\mathclose {}}=g{\mathopen {}\left (f{\mathopen {}\left (a\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}.

fr:title.text: Closure of partial functions under identity and composition

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Closure of partial functions under identity and composition

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Partial functions are closed under identity and composition in the following sense:

html:ol.html:li: For any set A, the identity relation \mathsf {id}_{A} \colon A\mathbin {\nrightarrow } A is functional.

For any sets A,B,C and functional relations f\colon A\mathbin {\rightharpoonup } B and g \colon B\mathbin {\rightharpoonup } C, the relational composite g\circ f \colon A\mathbin {\nrightarrow } C is functional.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: First, we prove that each identity relation \mathsf {id}_{A}\colon A\mathbin {\nrightarrow } A is functional. Fixing a,a_1,a_2\in A such that a=a_1 and a=a_2, we must show that a_1=a_2; this follows from transitivity and symmetry of equality.

Next, we fix partial functions f\colon A\mathbin {\rightharpoonup } B and g \colon B\mathbin {\rightharpoonup } C to check that g\circ f \colon A\mathbin {\nrightarrow } C is functional. Fixing a\in A and c_1,c_2\in C such that a\mathrel {{\mathopen {}\left (g\circ f\right )\mathclose {}}}c_1 and a\mathrel {{\mathopen {}\left (g\circ f\right )\mathclose {}}}c_2, we must check that c_1=c_2. By definition of the relational composite, we have b_1,b_2\in B such that a\mathrel {f}b_1\mathrel {g}c_1 and a\mathrel {f}b_2\mathrel {g}c_2. Because f\colon A\mathbin {\rightharpoonup } B is functional, we note that b_1 = b_2. Writing b=b_1=b_2, we therefore have b\mathrel {g}c_1 and b\mathrel {g}c_2. Because g\colon B\mathbin {\rightharpoonup } C is functional, we conclude that c_1=c_2.

fr:title.text: Relations and matrices

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Relations between finite sets can be desribed in a more computationally friendly way by their tabulation as matrices. In particular, we shall see in § that an {\mathopen {}\left (m\times n\right )\mathclose {}}-matrix over the boolean semiring is precisely the same thing as a relation from {\mathopen {}\left [m\right ]\mathclose {}} to {\mathopen {}\left [n\right ]\mathclose {}}, where {\mathopen {}\left [l\right ]\mathclose {}}={\mathopen {}\left \{i\mid 0\leq i < l\right \}\mathclose {}} is the set of natural numbers strictly smaller than l. Then we will see that relational composition is, under this correspondence, the same as matrix multiplication.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For natural numbers m and n, an {\mathopen {}\left (m\times n\right )\mathclose {}}-matrix over a semiring {\mathopen {}\left (S,0,\oplus ,1,\odot \right )\mathclose {}} is given by entries M_{i,j}\in S for all i\in {\mathopen {}\left [m\right ]\mathclose {}} and j\in {\mathopen {}\left [n\right ]\mathclose {}}.
